nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: Your child returns from your ex's home and says bedtime there is later and sweets are allowed after dinner.

nodes.prompt: How do you approach your co-parent about the mismatch?

choices.label: Calm message asking for clarity and proposing one shared list of rules
Send a frustrated text about undermining consistency
Let it slide for now and observe for a week

nodes.speaker: ex
nodes.text: They reply: Let's compare what we do in each house first.

nodes.speaker: ex
nodes.text: They respond defensively and the tone gets tense.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You note the differences and keep track for discussion.

nodes.summary: End of Act 1. You set the tone for how alignment talks may go.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You meet online to discuss rules. You each share current routines.

nodes.prompt: Choose an approach for bridging differences:

choices.label: Unified list: agree 3 non-negotiables across both homes
Zones of control: each parent leads specific domains
Coach mode: align on consequences/rewards, allow style differences

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You draft 3 shared rules: bedtime window, sweets cap, screen limit.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You assign domains: you lead bedtime; they lead screens; both share nutrition.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You write a simple consequence ladder and a weekly reward plan.

nodes.prompt: How will you record and revisit the plan?

choices.label: Rely on memory and text when needed

nodes.summary: End of Act 2. You shaped a first plan to test.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: A midweek school night runs late after an activity. Your child is tired and asks for extra screen time.

nodes.prompt: What do you do in the moment?

choices.label: Stick to the plan and offer a soothing alternative (story, stretch)
Grant an exception and log it for review
Argue about the rules in front of the child (call ex)

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: Your child settles after a short routine and falls asleep on time.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: The exception helps tonight; you note it to avoid a new pattern.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: The call becomes tense; bedtime gets later and emotions spike.

nodes.summary: End of Act 3. Real life tested the plan.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You and your co-parent review the week and the child's mood and sleep.

nodes.prompt: Choose how to adjust going forward:

choices.label: Keep the plan and add one clear exception rule
Simplify to 2 shared rules and more autonomy per home
Pause alignment talks and revisit next month

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You add a formal 'exception night' with a quick log so it does not become daily.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You streamline to what truly matters and reduce friction on style.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You defer deeper alignment; you agree to keep tone neutral in front of the child.

nodes.summary: End of Act 4. You finish with a workable plan or a clear pause.
